title: Do active duty military members look down on reservists? - Quora

response.answer_text: Do active duty military members look down on reservists? Initially no, but eventually yes.  The career of every Marine begins with the same brutal training. Everyone endures three months of Recruit Training, then School of Infantry, and a varying number of months of advance training depending on their job. But the similarities end upon completion of job training. Reservists will get their discharge papers, know which unit to join, and will do what’s known as Drill’s once a month, where they check in with their units for an entire weekend. At the most, they will go through two weeks of Active Training at some point during the year. Active Duty Marines on the other hand, are at the mercy of the needs of the Marine Corps. Want to get get stationed in Okinawa? Too bad, this unit over at Cherry Point needs a Marine! Selected East Coast for your duty station preference? Sucks to be you, you’re going to the West Coast because this unit needs more Marines! It’s not just the needs of the Marine Corps, but Active Duty Marines live the Marine Corps life 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, 365 days a year. It’s our full time job for the best or for the worst. We are constantly busy with safety standdowns, getting a haircut every single week, have to stand duty, clean the daylights out of our barracks rooms, attending half effort social events in the form of Mandatory Fun, and getting stuck on a six month deployment. Reservists on the other hand, don’t have to really deal with all of that. They think that their Drill’s are bad because every Drill is a culture shock to them, along with losing a weekend or two because of Reservist obligations. We on the Active Duty side, don’t understand why they’re complaining. “Why are you complaining about missing a class? We missed our kid’s birthday while being deployed you stupid moron!” Furthermore, they seem to enjoy their lifestyle as they resume their “normal” life after a weekend of being with their units. We on the other hand, can have somewhat of a normal life in the form of vacation, granted that our chain of command actually leaves us alone when we’re on leave. But I will give Reservists credit though, as it takes a lot of fortitude to switch from a civilian to a military mindset quickly, along with not atrophying in terms of job knowledge.

Yes and no. In some cases, it is merited but in other situations, the person doing the looking down would be wrong. I served in a reserve armoured reconnaissance regiment. We were under equipped, under supported and under experienced. However when asked to step forward, our members did so in large numbers. Not all were called up, but more than 10% were. They came back with a wealth of hands on experience. They made our training more practical, less “gamey” and more useful. The next time a call went out, our members were that much better prepared. Starting with Bosnia, (First) Gulf War, and Afghanistan all showed that our Reservists were able to pick up what they needed and perform effectively. I got out, went to school and got some civvy work experience. I eventually joined back up, the second time in the naval reserve. I did basic training a second time and then my officer qualification courses along with regular force direct entry officers (mostly lawyers, doctors, nurses, some other Reservists commissioned from the ranks with specialized civilian skills in high demand, etc.) Because I had joined back up as a Reserve Maritime Engineering Officer and there were no Reserve courses - just Reg Force qualifications - I took courses with the Regular Navy and found the course material not very hard, but the Regs memorized what they didn’t understand and could quote the manual. I had civvy experience and understood much of the material quite well because of its similarity to civvy equivalents. I placed in the top ten percent of my academic courses and upper half of the practical courses. I will skip over some. I was qualified as a diver so I requalified as a Reserve Diving Officer. In reality a diver requal course for a Reservist is identical to the Regular Force course and often Reservists and Regulars were loaded on the same course, space permitting. I had to take unpaid time off from my civvy job so I was motivated to successfully requal. That was one of the few times I found that being an officer was not much fun. We worked a lot more hours even though we were physically exhausted and had to be in the top half (really top 10%) of everything. Diving Officers are not allowed any mistakes unless they are in the divers’s favour. Officers also plan all the dives and lead some of the dives (NCM supervisors lead quite a few and plan some as well), and diving officers usually dive at some point each task. The NCM diving supervisors do similar work but the buck stops with the diving officer. I requal’d five times. My Reserve unit supported the local foreign military attache community as well as all Regular Force divers posted to the area (think of a Naval Reserve unit located in the same city as the nation’s capital), plus my own dive team of 10 Reservists. We had Brits, Americans, most NATO countries and by some peculiar arrangement any Soviet block divers who wanted to join us (post Berlin Wall). We also supported Regular Army Combat Divers and Air Force Search and Rescue Technicians. We were resourced for twice a month dives on weekends. We would sometimes have 20–25 divers show up for 10 sets of diving gear. We would often dive at an interesting local (ie within 2 hour drive) location and bring our portable compressor and eat in the field. I spent as much time begging for trucks and rations as I did planning the mission. My unit was the only non-army unit supported by the local base so we were not high on their priority. My divers had to dive at least once a month to remain current. Most of my divers (70% or more) dove two or more times a month. We sometimes dived twice a day. At one time my Commanding Officer and Coxswain were both divers and they put themselves in my team’s hands. We never lost a diver. We never hurt a diver. All that to say, when I asked the Regular Force divers for planning and operational input, they were often quite happy to leave the hard work to the Reservists because they trusted us not to endanger anyone’s life or limb. If you are a diver, you will know that trust is earned.

Reservist no but National Guard yes. And if you don't know the difference, a lot of reservist are Active duty who got out but didn't want to separate themselves entirely. Most of the reserve unit that I was in this was the case. They were like me had done a term on active duty but because they had kids or other reasons didn't reenlist but still wanted to serve. National guard on the other hand tend to mostly have spent their time in Guard units except for their time on active duty as part of training or a call up. Spending time with Guard units at JRTC NTC and in Iraq there are a few things I noticed about them that stood out. They tent to be out of shape, not as big an issue with units that spend most of their time in the rear, but some national guard units are combat arms units and it doesn't instill confidence when you see a guy to fat for his body armor. They tend to be far less disciplined. We shared guard duty with a national guard MP battalion on the main post in Mosul, Iraq. On more than one occasion we found guardsmen asleep of extremely inattentive at their post. It was not unusual to see them with dirty weapons and gear. This I don't know what to call. In country it was pretty easy to spot the national guardsman and some reservist by their constant going around with their rifles slung over their shoulder, barrels pointed strait up into the air. The only time its ok to carry your rifle around that way in a combat zone is if you need to use both hands to carry something. And even then usually you want to use a shoulder sling or tactical sling if you could get your hands on one. Prevalence of I-didnt-sign-up-for-this-itis. The national guards units tend to have a much higher amount of soldiers claiming that's not my job or this isn't why I joined the army. I got to the point that I was gonna slug the next guardist who told me they only signed up for the money for college like they didn't have to earn it. And an overabundance of caution almost to the point of being borderline cowardice. Caution in itself is fine, its what can keep you alive in some situations but if you are cautious to the point of being downright slow then you are an easy target and your slowness if gonna get you and other people killed. That being said the National Guardsman are not that bad and their deficiencies are not from a lack of will to do their duties. They mostly don't live the life or spend the time in the field their military bearing and discipline reflect that. I noticed they tend to have outstanding medical, aviation, and transportation specialist. As usual there can be exception and there was on. The 256th Infantry brigade and the 30th Armored brigade. Both were well led fairly disciplined units that didn't need to be babysat. They were impressive by National Guard standards.

Of course, there are always those who don’t understand the role that the Reserve Component plays within the Total Force. Joint doctrine recognizes the Total Force as the sum of the Regular Component, the Reserve Component, the other two Services of the Uniformed Services (the Public Health Service and NOAA), all retirees of all those organizations (both Regular and Reserve retirees), and the totality of the industrial, economic, informational, and organizational assets of the United States. The last time all of these entities were coordinated in a truly meaningful way was WWII…FDR had entire Councils and “Czars” of Industry, etc., to support the war effort while meeting the basic needs of the American citizens, whose standard of living generally went up significantly even during the war, and even higher afterwards. A member of the Active Component (the common term for the legally correct term “Regular Component” as defined in Title 10 of the US Code) who looks down on their fellow servicemembers as members of the Reserve Component is largely just displaying the usual biases common to EVERYONE in the military…we all have them. For example, I am particularly partial to Marines, both active and reserve. As most servicemembers grow in experience and seniority, especially those exposed to other services and joint organizations, much biased thought disappears, replaced with new found knowledge about the capabilities of Sister Services, Joint organizations, Combatant Commands, the National Command Authorities, combined/coalition/allied warfare, the elements of national power, and the Total Force. And how it all fits together. For the highest levels of Professional Military Education, especially Joint PME, one of the desired outcomes is not only mastery of one’s own parent Service, but a solid understanding of the differences and strengths/weaknesses of one’s own Service Reserve/Guard elements, and the Reserve/Guard of each Service…including the USCG as one of the Armed Forces but not part of the DoD, and the Uniformed Services comprised of the Armed Forces plus the PHS and NOAA, and the rest of it… The desired pinnacle of the JPME system, along with the equivalent of 36 full months (to the day!) of “Joint duty” which could include Interagency and/or Combined duty with allies, is recognition as a Joint Qualified Officer (formerly Joint Specialty Officer, before the process was thoroughly revamped and Reserve officers were invited into the process), who is supposed to have mastery of the doctrine, operational concepts, systems and programs, and roles/missions/functions of their own Service (active and reserve components), but also the full gamut of the Joint system, bringing the best and brightest of ANY Service, active or reserve, to the problem at hand rather than being tied down with primitive Service (and Component) biases…

Former National Guard NCO, OCS graduate, 11-series MOSs (Infantry) There will always be instances where one group of individuals looks down on the other. Sometimes it's tradition, sometimes it's truly earned, sometimes it's ignorance...there is no one answer there. The tradition part I will accept, because deep down everyone knows that we all wear the same uniform and a bullet doesn't discriminate based on active duty status or MOS. At the reception station for basic training (Ft. Benning, 1984) I was processed with a whole platoon of National Guard recruits from Nebraska. I remember the sergeant leading us through those couple days telling us (paraphrasing, it's >30 years!) that the active Army treats NG's as "No-Go"s (NG being used simultaneously for "National Guard" and "No Go"). But he challenged us to break that cycle. I like to think most did well that cycle. During my service years, we frequently were trained by active Army personnel, many being from the 10th Mountain Division (Ft. Drum). To be honest I didn't detect being thought less of for not being active. The active duty trainers challenged us mentally and physically, and trained "with" us (not just "to" or "at" us). I felt their positive comments after each exercise was genuine; during downtime they would just chat with us like we'd been friends for a long time. Their Infantry was their way of life which presented one set of challenges. Our Infantry was something we managed to balance with civilian careers and responsibilities...in short, not only were we all Infantry, but we all had challenges and difficulties to deal with in our lives. I know I'm speaking from a reservist point of view, and I welcome feedback from active duty veterans on this topic.

My first ‘contact’ with reservists was during the parachute course at the German Airborne school. It was our second or third jump and the weather was extremely bad. Our instructors hoped that the sky would clear up during our approach on the drop zone, but it didn’t. It was raining, the wind was strong and we were told that there would be no jumping. However, there was a group of reservists on the aircraft with us and I remember that we all had looked a little bit down on them when they showed up at the airfield: Some of them wore their hair much too long for our taste, others had a beer belly, and they really looked like ‘weekend warriors’ and not like professional soldiers. While the machine turned around to fly us back to the airport, one of them went to the jumpmaster and told him that they wanted to jump. The jumpmaster thought about it for a few seconds, smiled and nodded his head. All the reserve soldiers on the plane were experienced paratroopers with many jumps under their belt and if they wanted to risk it, it was their problem. Our aircraft made another approach on the drop zone and while the ‘weekend warriors’ were jumping out of the plane, we were watching them, feeling a bit stupid. What I could always observe with soldiers of the reserve was that they were extremely motivated. Their skills were sometimes a little bit rusty, but they more than compensated their lack of knowledge with dedication and a willingness to work. In the German army, a reserve soldier gets promoted much faster than an active duty soldier and our buddies from the reserve almost always outranked us by at least two or three ranks, but fortunately, most of them were smart enough not to question our authority. Most of the reserve soldiers I worked with had a relaxed and friendly attitude and training with them was much more rewarding than usual. They were thankful for everything we taught them and the best of it, they never complained! Do active duty soldiers look down on reservists? Some of them do, but it’s a big mistake!

Look down? I can see where you are going with this. First off, lets clarify that “reservist” are actually Soldier from two of the three components of the total Army - US Army (active guys), Army National Guard and the U.S Army Reserve. Note there is no “s” at the end of Reserve. There was a time (lets say back in the 80s), when the million man active duty army would look at the Reserve Components as a back up to what was going on in Europe. This was basically knowing that the RC wouldn't be able to get into the fight until 30 days after it kicked off. By that time it was theorized it would be over in a bad way. Today, after Desert Shield/Storm, Kosovo, Iraq/Afghanistan and multiple other missions, the Active Army can neither go to war without the additional combat power supplied by the Army Guard, nor without the support structure the Army Reserve provides. As a full time reservist, I work with the Active duty force daily. Most of them wouldn’t know I am in the Army Reserve until I tell them. These perception of “looking down” on the Reserve Components is more of people who don’t understand what the RC brings to the fight because they are so close to the tactic problem; they can’t see the big strategic picture. They are also ignorant morons that probably don’t realize that the beans/bullets, air cover, transportation, security, communications, medical support, and additional combat power to their left and right are members of the National Guard and Army Reserve. They also don’t realize that a chuck if the RC manpower are former Active components soldiers serving their Nation after they left the AC. Don’t fall into that mental trap of looking down on reservist. That’s a great way of getting ostracized by 2/3s of the Army.

Some do. Back in the 1990s (at the time of the Bosnia upset) my USAR unit, a quartermaster company, did a 21-day annual training at Baumholder in Germany, which at the time was the home of the 1st Armored Division. We were assigned to the division’s main support battalion to help clear a large backlog of incoming Class IX (repair parts) that was flowing to the division to bring a lot of not-mission-capable equipment back on line. It turned out to be a huge backlog and we worked two 12-hour shifts for twelve straight days to move that Class IX along. I was the NCOIC of the overnight shift. Our reception at the battalion was somewhat less than cordial. The general opinion seemed to be that a bunch of half-stepping weekend warriors couldn’t get the job done. My own impression was that the real half-steppers were the RA soldiers who’d allowed the backlog to become so large. I don’t blame the lower-ranking enlisted troops; they merely took their cue from the slackers who were supposed to be their leaders. Actually we reservists were delighted to have been given a real-world mission. It made a nice change from the simulated training exercises that were our usual portion. Within a few days we’d made a huge dent in the backlog. Supposedly the battalion commander was royally cheesed off at his own people, who no doubt had been showering him with a litany of excuses for their inability to move things along. About a month after we returned to home station, our higher headquarters received a letter from the 1st Armored Division DISCOM (Division Support Command) commander, commending our company’s outstanding performance of duty. I like to think that on the flip side, the leadership of that main support battalion was treated to an ass-kicking session for letting a bunch of reservists show them up.

Unfortunately, some do, but they’re the exception. When my medical unit deployed to Iraq in ‘04, the 1st ID was just rotating out to be replaced by the 42nd ID, the famed “Rainbow Division” of WWI and WWII and now a Reserve unit. We were in an afternoon briefing being chaired by a captain in the 1st ID, who made some choice remarks about Reserve units in general and the 42nd in particular. To say they were inappropriate and not well received would be an understatement, but I found him to be the rare exception—as well as an egotistical, condescending ass. What he failed utterly to comprehend is that a large percentage of Reserve units are ex-active duty and equal or superior to him in training and experience PLUS they bring a unique skill set from being in the private community that active duty units may not have. Yes, we may do things a bit differently, but that doesn’t mean we don’t get it done equally as well. Whether you’re a Reservist or active duty, you’re judged on your ability to fulfill your mission requirements and work with other units—period. During our extended deployment, we were very well regarded and received first by the 42nd and subsequently by the unit that replaced them—the 3rd ID, a totally professional and highly competent division—and I had no complaints about them, either. I wouldn’t judge the 1st ID solely by the actions of one dimwitted captain—I’m sure they’re every bit as hard-charging as the other active duty units in the Army.

Some do, but I think most of us who have worked with Reservists really appreciate them. I was a Sergeant on Active Duty at an Army hospital in Germany when the first Gulf War spun up. We had lots of Reserve soldiers deployed to our unit to help us diagnose and treat our troops who were sick, injured, or wounded during operations in the Gulf. At first, I guess I did look down on them — especially the ones who were much older than us but had equal or lower rank. Then I learned a few things. Many of those Reservists worked in civilian jobs that matched their military job, and some of those had a lot more experience than my people and I did. Some of them had different civilian professions, but maintained their military skill sets, so they could sometimes do more than we could. We all busted our butts to get the work done, but at the end of a shift, they went back to the barracks (to maybe call home to their spouses and kids) while I got to go home to my wife at our apartment. For me and my people, the war didn’t change a whole lot of things. But those Reservists set aside their regular lives (and some took huge pay cuts) to travel halfway around the world to help us accomplish the mission. And through it all, I heard precious little bitching and moaning from them. Nothing but respect for those folks.

To some degree, I did. I’d like to point out that I first joined the Army Reserves and then got an Army ROTC scholarship before going active duty as an Infantry Officer. My main complaint with the reserves and national guard is in the proficiency of the units. These guys play Soldier one weekend a month and for two weeks a year. They simply don’t have the same quantity or quality of training available to them as an active duty unit that gets to play Army 365 days a year. My squad leader when I was in the reserves in 1997 was a Vietnam veteran and a janitor at the local elemtary school. During our unit PT test, I was considered the PT stud of the unit after getting an APFT score of 270 (nobody else was even close to me). That’s a solid score, but certainly nothing special. When I was deployed to Iraq, I ran into a National Guard unit where one of the guys was so fat that he couldn’t close his body armor and instead wore it like an open vest. You can’t make this stuff up. Sometime around 1998 my reserve unit was being alerted to go to a humanitarian mission in Haiti. The next drill, after being alerted that we were going to be deployed in a few months, a whole slew of women in the unit showed up pregnant and were conveniently unable to deploy. I was in a medical unit and we were going to be assigned to a nice cushy duty in a hospital. The idea of being deployed so freaked these people out that they were running around trying to find any reason not to be able to deploy!

Not exactly. At least not in my experience. There is concern for their combat readiness. They are often relatively poorly equipped and have less time to train. That is no fault of their own, but if I were a general I would place their elements in places I felt were either less likely to see combat or (if we reached a level of combat we have not seen in generations) in areas that we could afford to lose. They are good. Worthy of as much respect and honor as every other person in uniform. Citizen soldiers. Volunteers. …but given the straight choice between them and active duty? In most military specialties they are best kept in reserve if possible. They just haven’t handled their equipment every day non-stop like active duty soldiers do. (I’d take a reservist unit over an active duty unit in certain jobs. Frankly military doctors lag a bit compared to civilians. IT folks in the military know the antiquated systems better, but don’t have the range of experience that citizen soldiers who work in the IT field at home do. I’d like a mix of reservists and active duty in many Transportation roles; Everyones life experience will teach them different tricks. Military linguists are typically a bit rigid and military oriented in their focus, whereas the Mormon Church does a damned good job teaching their missionaries to speak languages in a way that local populations react better to. MPs can benefit from reservists who are cops in the real world. The list goes on.)

They do. Until they work with them.Case in point, last deployment was with the Army Reserve in '11. While the MPs did their training we cooks went to a DFAC on Ft Bliss for our train up. We had a mix of prior active duty and only reservist time Soldiers who had never worked in a kitchen before.At first the active duty cooks were referring to us as National Guard (not a term of endearment). By the end several of the prior service guys were being asked "why did you leave active duty?" and "any way you could transfer over to us?". To be fair they had a heavier load of privates and brand new specialists on their shifts than I normally saw. But while they saw me as an Sgt E-5 at first ( promotion to which normally occurs with the first 5 years of service), they realized working with me that I had over 15 years doing that job under my belt. That kind of experience being common is one of the benefits of a Reserve unit. As with anything else, it tends to be easier to make fun of someone/thing when you don't personally know them. Once you work with them a bit, you can often find yourself impressed.

Some do, they consider Reservists and National Guard to be “weekend warriors”. When deployed though, the reservists usually prove themselves to be good soldiers. There are even some advantages the reserve soldiers enjoy. Reserve troops tend to be older, and more experienced. We also have a lot of different skills in a unit than the active component does. Active duty troops often enlist at 18 and have been trained and are experienced in one job, the job the military trained them to do. A Reserve or Guard unit consists of people who all have very different careers in the civilian world. When we trained at Ft Dix, the heat in the motor shops didn’t work. The regular Army guys put in a work request, while next door,we had a plumber who just repaired the boiler. We had everything from plumbing and heating guys to a barber. IT pros to carpenters. Eventually, some of the active Army units came to us when they needed things done. Any that initially looked down on us didn’t after that.

Truthfully, of course they do. They go into a nice clean armory one weekend a month, wearing starched, pressed uniform and sit around telling stories and playing cards. They send out for pizza, dink around in the afternoon, and then go home to their wives & families. For that, they get Equal pay and benefits, equal respect and treatment, and all the privileges of rank equal to the guy laying in the mud, being eaten alive by bugs, starving, possibly bleeding, and exhausted from bustin' his ass. Don't tell me you are my "equal" until you've walked a mile in my boots, sacrificed what I have had to give, and slept where I have had to sleep. Yes, their uniforms may have the same patches, they may have a shirt full of award ribbons, and they may have even been on active duty once "back in '98", but you ain't a soldier until you've done some soldierin' pal. I'm not talking about wearing your uniform to the restaurant on Memorial Day for a Free lunch or showing your YD at Home Depot to get your 10% discount. I'm talking about working around the clock in inclement weather, 3 days & nights straight, with no sleep, minimal cold food, sweatin' your ass off - while being responsible for the safety and welfare of 50 junior enlisted people, like I've been doing. THEN you will be my "Equal". Until then, you are a "Wannabe". I knew a Navy Chief who had served 28 years in the Reserves in 1968... A Navy Chief who had NEVER been stationed on a ship. Think about that for a minute. Not Trained, Not Ready, Not Capable ...he had passed all of his Bookwork & Exams, but had NO IDEA what it took to run his Division on a Warship at sea.Just WHO was he supposed to be the equal to? He expected a fat pension for "Service to his country" and he had been at home with his family every night of his life.

Depends on the MOS/AFSC, I was a 4N1X1 Surgical Tech in the Air Force stationed at a army hospital. When we had 68Whiskey reservists show up they usually had no idea what they were doing, a lot used the excuse "this isn't my job." They had accepted that it was ok not to know their MOS because most drill weekends they were usually hanging out instead of doing surgical procedures or learning to better themselves. If you signed the dotted line you should at least know the bare minimum of your job, im not saying be a resident expert but you should at least be able to do it, know what equipment is, and somewhat know what do to. These people walked into OR's like they had never been there. I also have friends who are Guard/Reserve that do their MOS/AFSC in the civilian sector and they are subject matter experts. They know the ins and outs of their job and their unit is blessed to have them. So yes sometimes we look down on guard/reservists but for me at least its not because they aren't Active duty, its if they can do the job they signed up to do to help the mission.

IF, some do and some don't, see all the given answers for reasoning, then it goes something like this: Special Forces look down on active duty conventional combat troops, conventional combat troops look down on active duty paper pushers, active duty paper pushers look down on reservists, with reservist combat troops looking down on them. Specialized careers, like anything to do with nukes or Intel, look down on everyone else, with combat troops looking down at them in return. Everyone looks up to the chaplains and whoever is doing the cooking. Everyone looks down on the paper pushers who screw up your pay twice a month. But don't you dare, as a civilian, look down on anyone who has ever taken the oath of enlistment or received a commission. Or as someone who has taken that oath ever leave a fellow military member high and dry. The joking aside, and half of it it is just joking, like when families have their pecking orders, it's one big family. With that weird uncle with a van that shows up once a month.

Back in the 1970’s US Army, yes, there was a considerable disdain for people that joined the National Guard or the Army Reserve. My father in particular noted how poorly a National Guard platoon fared against a squad of Vietnam vets that had come back recently, being among those vets himself. The squad set a simple ambush and sprung it upon the NG soldiers who fell into a panic, and culminated in the radioman for the platoon calling in a simulated CAS mission directly on them. He commented after I had joined and the things I had told him I had been trained on, that the National Guard had gotten far better. Indeed, at the time I had joined, 63% of deployed soldiers to active combat zones were National Guard or Reservists. He was proud of me for volunteering, and highly impressed with how far the NG had come since the 1970’s. And there is definitely something to be said about soldiers that can maintain the standards that regular Army soldiers must meet, while holding down a life and job outside the military sphere.

Reservists can be active duty Personel as well. Their ID cards have an “R” (as in USNR) after their respective branch. Then they return to civilian life and continue to serve in standby status. Ther is no reason to look down on Reservist because they serve just like regular Military. I was both. I started in the Reserves and then before I went active, switched to the regular Navy. As such I no longer had the “R” designation and I must admit I was glad to not be looked down on by the other regulars. But it is a mistaken notion that they are somehow beneath those in the regular service branch they are serving in. They perform the same duties while active and during their drills. The fact they are willing to be on call at the will of the President says a lot. Thos has been the norm for reservists since 9/11. This means they have to leave their jobs and families in an instant and return to active duty. But they have continued staying current with their respective specialties and deserve the same respect as any other member of the military.

yes and no - If you are active duty combat arms, you live in the field. When I was active duty, combat battalions went to the field either as a battalion or a company or a platoon every Monday and came back on Thursday night or Friday. Practically every week. If you are combat arms in the Guard or Reserves - you may have done that at one time and you are probably just as knowledgeable and capable, BUT you haven’t worked together as a team as long and as regularly as the active duty teams. You are NOT going to be as quick or as good. There are some exceptions in the combat service support and combat support fields. I was an engineer in the Guard after my active duty time. The battalion I was in - almost every senior NCO was a project manager for some civilian construction company. The NCOs and troops that operated the Hyexes, bulldozers, road graders, etc. They all worked in the civilian world on the same type of equipment every single day. Compared to the active duty counterparts - not even close. The active duty simply doesn’t have as much time on the equipment, money in the budget or projects to do to keep the same level of expertise. I suspect it is the same in some other support fields. So if you are combat arms active duty you are going to look at the reservists and say they aren’t up to speed and if you are combat support or service support then it is possible that you will look at the active duty and say - why aren’t you guys better at this?

In the US armed forces, there is a tendency to. Bear in mind that many active duty military don’t make a distinction between “reserve” and “national guard”. In both (the n.g. in particular), the quality can vary widely, from personnel just out of the active-duty side to personnel who have never been on the active duty side. During Desert Shield/Storm/Calm the performance differences tended to fade after 90–180 days. I still remember calling up a national guard unit (and this was typical) to talk to the S-4 (logistics). It took a while to find the person, as the “official” S-4 was really doing the S-1 (personnel) duties, the “real” S-4 was “officially” something else. It was explained to me that they moved the titles around for career progression reason (from the active side) but just kept doing their “actual” jobs - rather than learning their new jobs and positions. Another time I was running and noticed a “clump” of Lt’s hanging around a CSM - like on a street corner. I had never seen that before, it looked pretty unprofessional. I suspect they “grew out of it” as they were exposed to “real” active duty units.

Sometimes the active duty folks were jealous of us because we were part-timers, sometimes the reservists were lousy Sailors and had attitudes. During Desert Storm my Navy Reserve medical unit, (field hospital servicing the Marines), served in the war zone near to the active duty medical unit. The Marines preferred our Reserve medial unit because they said we were nicer and more efficient that the active duty medical unit. As Reservists we were motivated to serve and show the Navy we were worth all the resources they expended on us; the Active duty medical unit was peeved because they were all pulled from a stateside Naval Hospital and sent to the field hospital away from their regular hospital duties, away from their families and were there a lot longer than us. So they had reasons to be peeved.

It depends. Based on my limited experience as a reservist it depends on how long people have been in and what their job is. Active duty combat support and support guys loved us, both for providing extra manpower during exercises and for helping them with problems ranging from paperwork to things they should do if they decide to go reserve or leave the service. Only group I’ve seen look down on us are infantry, but that's because they're infantry, they've been trained and raised to believe they are the top of the food chain (which for better or worse, combat arms is the tip of the spear for a reason), in which case they don't really look down on reservists because we're reservists but because we weren't infantry. Though I will admit, they loved raining hell on the few reserve and national guard infantry guys we had because they were not full timers anymore.

Sorta…spent four yrs active duty and five and a half in the reserves. One Saturday morning at Submarine Base Bangor I’m driving up and I see about 40–50 Marines standing around.I knew they wern’t Bangor Marines because we were very sharp in cammies and they looked like crap. Also knew they wern’t boots so maybe they were from Marine Barracks Whidbey Island or a Mar Det from a carrier parked at the Bremerton Shipyard doing field ops at Camp Wesley Harris. Asked a dude who they were and he said they were reservist from some landing support company in Tacoma conducting swim qual. Asked him if he knew Numbnuts from boot camp;said Numbnuts stop showing up months earlier and was listed as a deserter. Hated reservist after seeing them for no reason other than they didn’t have to put up with crap day in and day out and some were going to college. Saw some reserve Combat Engineers at K-Bay right before my EAS and hated them too.Two months later I’m in the reserves and attending college. “Go Figure”

My unit didn’t really work with reservists, but we would see them often in bases near our own. I remember the first time I met a reservists unit. It was kind of a shock to me. All the reservists were aged between 28 years old to 45 years old, running around base, taking down orders, preparing gear and vehicles, just like my team and I were doing all day, except that the majority of us were nineteen years old. Seeing these men who have long finished their military service, leaving their families, work, studies, buisness and life, to guard and serve Israel for 3 weeks every year was astonishing to watch. These guys have everything to lose, and have all been in the worst situations, just to go back to hell once again, and make sure themselves that no threat will ever reach their families. Everything I thought sucked about my service was gone. I had nothing more to complain about. Nothing but respect for these guys.

upvoters.user_id: Lok Hei Isaac Isaac Tsang - Cassia

response.answer_text: I experienced both sides of the coin. I served active duty enlisted, reserve enlisted, active duty officer, reserve officer. As a reservist when I went in to do my drills, many times the active duty force was not prepared for my arrival and had little for me to do. These drills are called Inactive Duty Training (IDTs) periods so when they didn’t have work for me to do, I found training items that I needed to accomplish. When that happened, I was pretty much useless to the active duty staff. However, personnel shortfalls for needed overseas tours were always evident, so I volunteered to fill many deploying to Saudi Arabia, Bosnia, the Republic of Georgia, and Iraq. I deployed so my supervisors didn’t have to, or they didn’t have to pull someone from the field to deploy. On one deployment I was injured and wasn’t allowed to work for six months while undergoing physical therapy treatment. When I finally returned to my active duty unit, I was told I was not needed anymore (new supervisor) and to find a new job. I quickly found a new job within a new organization where I was utilized more efficiently than at my previous office. From there I deployed to Iraq and was recognized by promotion to Colonel and retired with a Legion of Merit Medal Legion of Merit - Wikipedia.

During the Vietnam War, yes, because the Reserves and National Guard were never used in Vietnam. When the Draft Lottery was established those with low numbers could join a Guard unit and not have to worry about being drafted. All that’s changed with the Wars in the Middle East. Almost all of the Guard and Reserve unit have been mobilized and sent to the Middle East to fight. Even the National Guard’s 19th and 20th Special Forces Group have been sent and many have been KIA. So yes today there is much respect for the part time soldiers.

A broader question might be why is anybody looked down upon by active duty Marines? If you’re not familiar, read some of the Quora comments posted by current and retired Marines. You may find your answer there as well. In general, reservists may not be deemed as ‘real’ Marines….because they are in the reserves and not on the front line. However, I think this may have changed a bit when so many reservists were called up during the Iraq and Afghanistan conflicts. This call-up turned them from reservists into active-duty. These reservists were now on the front lines and considered as equal. It’s a prevalent attitude among military personnel, but not one that is shared by ALL military personnel. I think you may find just as many active duty Marines don’t have this attitude as those who do. I guess one way you could look at it is to chalk it up to a ‘military thing.’

I think during Vietnam Reservist and Guard got a lot of hell, and probably for good reason. (It was before my time.) But, since Gulf War 1 and going forward, Guard and Reservist call ups became common and they were leaving their lives and jobs to serve. Us Active Duty folks, that WAS our jobs, our lives—but the Reserves sacrificed a lot. So, was there good natured ball busting about “Week End Warriors”? Yeah, but there was also a lot of respect.

When I was active I had done some training exercises with different reserve units. It was the worst. I fukn hate them and they suck. Most active guys that go reserve after 4 yrs. will most likely go back to active duty. The prior active duty guys on reserve are looked at like azhols because of how they act and are (always killers). As too te reserve side they’re laid back. When i was doing training exercises with them they fuked up a lot and were redone. Most only did the basic of what they had too. That’s not enough man because when your out there you need to be able to do and give your all. That’s what going above and beyond is.

We know reservists don't have nearly the same amount of training as Regular Army. We don't fault them with this. They are part of our same team, answer to the same chain of command. We may pay close attention to see how they react when the sh*t hits the fan but we also do the same with our Regular Army Compatriots.National Guard was a different matter. They had a chain of command different from ours. Their oath of enlistment was also different from ours. I wouldn't call it looking down on them. It was more like the way a truck driver would look at a store clerk.

It's not that reservists themselves are looked down on- seriously. It's more the training that is looked down on. As a reservist, you practice your job once a month. You simply can't be as good at it as someone who practices daily. The reservist can't help it- they don't set the training schedule, and 5.56mm ammunition costs something like $3 and change for a magazine- there simply isn't enough bullets or money to train every infantry reservist to be a marine corps rifleman. That being said, reservists tend to be able to approach situations outside of the box, and bring lots of external concepts to a problem.

In Israel, all my older cousins are reservists. Their younger cousins who are still draftees worship them and ask them for advice. Israel is a citizen army. The army reserves are a crucial and needed part of life, as the support, backup and comrades of the enlisted soldiers. Anyone who would look down on reservists is a fool. My American friend is a reservist in the army, and enlisted soldiers are quite respectful of her experience, intelligence and expertise. She may be a reserves officer, but she’s still an officer.

Exactly the opposite. A man in his 40′s with MS. Degree, 3 little kids, a wife, and a very high paying job gets an order, leaves his job, family and friends to drive 2 hours to some goddamned place. Puts on his uniform, and runs up and down the hills while carrying heavy equipment, after his last push up was several years ago. After that he's going to guard Israelis in a hostile environment while putting his own life in danger. Nothing but respect for these guys.

A lot of it depends on the Reservists and the AD people involved. After active duty, I went to grad school, but I transferred to the Reserve component. I figured I could do a year and one annual training exercise, and if I didn't care for it, I could transfer to the inactive Reserves (IRR). I was active duty during Desert Storm, but my division wasn't sent. Then on my first drill weekend, there was a Class A uniform inspection at my new Reserve unit. I literally went from being discharged from duty on Monday to getting my orders to my Reserve unit on Wednesday to reporting for drill Friday night. My new CO said “don't worry about getting your unit patches changed; just wear your uniform as you would have in your old unit and we’ll get you squared away this weekend.” So I show up for drill, and my Reserve unit had been to Desert Storm and I hadn't; they had received decorations and combat patches for it. That earned them some credibility in my eyes real quick. But they liked that I was fresh off active duty, and they often asked me to conduct a block of common task training on drill weekend; anything would do; NBC operations, field first aid, land navigation. They seemed to feel that I had done it all more recently than they had (maybe so) and could give a good presentation. At least in my experience, there was respect in both directions.

Went to basic with guys going reserve and ng. They did everything I had to do. Worked with reserves once. Us regular army couldn't believe how casual the officers and 1st Sgt's where kinda made us jealous. They were also not as in practice in fieldcraft as we were. They improved quite a bit in their 2 weeks of active duty though. Never worked with national guard. Our mortar platoon could pull up and be ready to fire in a minute. The reserve platoon was closer to 3 minutes. Still within army standards but understandably slower than regulars. At the end of their 2 weeks down to a minute and 30. I was an expert gunner every time we tested. My squad leader regular gunners were twice as fast as me. None of them could run a plotting board in double the time I could. So I was on the radio and board and the best gunners were on the guns. The reserve guys knew what to do they just didn't practice as much as we did. On the rifle range they were just as good as any regular platoon. Some guys would shoot expert and some not. Everyone qualified though just like us.

Only if they suck at their jobs. But we look down on anyone who sucks. We do understand their limitations because of their position. We are aware that there will be some training short falls, but this isn't a hit on their potential. But, they train one weekend a month, two weeks a year. They usually have a short training run up before deployment, but it still isn't the same. But, usually by the half way point in their deployment, they're up to speed. We do admire them for what they do. It can't be easy to jump from civilian life to military life at the drop of a hat. We also reserve the right to make fun of them. But, if you're not getting made fun of, it means we don't love you. And if you're Army, you're still tougher than the Air Force.

There’s a bit. Mostly it’s inter-group trash talk, like Packers and Bears fans. We had Reserve drill instructors in basic training and for the next several weeks we heard “I know those Reservists couldn’t have screwed you up that badly in only two weeks!” Antidotes: Military bearing. Courtesy, proper gear and uniform, haircuts.Know your job. Security, communications, map reading (if you’re good with maps you are gold), vehicle maintenance, reporting, guard duty.Pitch in. Several times as an E-7 I had junior enlisted praise me for pitching in on rolling out camo nets, cleaning overlays, etc. Not a shot at their own NCO’s, who had duties I didn’t have, but it made a good impression.If you pull these off, within a day or two they don’t care whether you’re Reserve or not.
Yep. One of the more colorful euphemisms is “tampons”. “Use once a month or as needed.” If that isn’t disrespect, I don’t want to know what is.

Back in the day yes. The reserve and national guard were never deployed and it was considered the easy way out and a way to avoid combat. And I feel there was a difference between us AD types and the USAR. Overtime the USAR became assigned to specific active units (CAPSTONED) to deploy with that AD unit. Still no one really thought it would happen. Until it did. Desert Shield changed all that. Shock and Awe as the reserves were ordered up in huge numbers. In fact the Army could not sustain itself in the field because so much of the logistics tail had found its way into the reserves. The reserves earned respect. The National Guard too. No one asks if anyone is reserve or active anymore. We all wear the same uniform and take the same risks.

30 years ago the reservist sat around in the armory and just drank coffee and did some busy work. A lot were over weight and lazy. Of course one of the problems was the reserves and national guard got very little money from the department of defense and always second rate , old equipment. That had been the case since the immediate post Vietnam War time frame. The public did not support our troops. Not true at least since Operation Desert Storm. Now they get much more money and relative training. First line equipment is being provided. Why ? Because today the members of our guard and reserve are highly motivated, educated and patriotic individuals. The truth of the matter is TODAY we cannot fight any war (even limited wars) without the assistance of the great individuals of our guard and reserves !

Do active duty military members look down on reservists? No. When I was with the 10th Mountain Division, we went to Panama and for some reason, there was a guy who normally worked on the stock exchange, acting as a Company Commander for one of the Infantry Companies. I don’t know what strings were pulled and what program got a reservist command time in a combat arms green tab slot and I still kind of wonder about how that happened. As a 1LT, I called him Sir and he was fulfilling his role as expected.

Some do. when I was a staff sergeant reservist, doing my two weeks summer training at Fort Sill, I had to go to the emergency room for an illness. The soldier at the desk - another staff sergeant - asked me if I was entited to all the ribbons I was wearing (I’m a Vietnam veteran). I answewred him, “Yes. Are you?”

Only at their own peril. Generally speaking the reservist has had the same basic and AIT training as the active duty soldier. Often they are prior service filling out their 6 or 8 year commitment after having served on active duty. Those who stay longer than the mandatory time are committed. They give of their time while holding down full time jobs or working on their educations. Currently we have Reserve and National Guard units pulling tours all over the world, relieving the demands on the active duty forces. The reserves are part of the total package, (Yes, besides my 28 years active duty, I did have 4 years in the Army Reserve while I was in college.)

Yes. Met a guy from my old school a while back. He’d joined the Irish Army straight after graduation, and, me being me, we had a grand old chat about military matters. Midway through the conversation, I mentioned to him that I’d applied to join the Reserves. “Oh, you’re joining the sandbags?” he exclaimed, and laughed. Training two hours a week, one full day a month, and barred from being deployed overseas does not exactly endear the Reserve to the rest of the Defence Forces.

Most generaly are too busy to notice or care about who is a reser or not. They do care about whether that person has any applicable experience in the field or combat experience. Also a quick side note, when I went through the green zone in 2009 with my 4 man group to fix some communications at other sites, a very nice Sgt Major took us for a tour of Saddam Hussein’s palace. Even got a few photos of our time there…. and she was a reservist.

For the most part Marines see other Marines equally so that stuff would never happen, actually I'm pretty sure I'm full of shit, in fact I know I am, of course active duty would give a reservist the stink eye, that's just how it is, how ever there some reservists who have some serious experience, especially the ones with any combat and they don't get that and are well respected. The thing with the military is that doing your job well or if you're one of the best at it, that transcends rank, age, job title every thing, just like in the civilian world, if you're one of the best at your job you're afforded certain luxuries or given more leeway when it comes to pushing boundaries so there are some reservists who are treated like royalty.

Yes, but it's no worse than a Marine calling the Air Force lame. At the end of the day Marines respect the Air Force and know that everyone who serves is needed for their job. That being said, reservists are “looked down on” by service members in their own branch as well. Most reserve units have less strict and rigorous PT so that doesn't help.

A few do, but they don’t last very long. I had someone do that to me when I was in the reserves and made some choice comments. His problem, I was a second class and he but a seaman. So I made him go find some flight line and a bucket of steam to clean it. His first class asked what was up and I explained it, he laughed and let the order stand. Once that seaman realize he got caught, he complained and I pointed out most everyone in my reserve unit WAS active duty at one time. Fixed him right up.

In the 70s I would work with the AF reserves during their monthly 2 days and yearly 30 days. At the time we did not think much of them. They would show up and we would pair them up with an active duty person to help train them. At lunch we would start trying to schedule lunch and find out most of the were missing and being told that they were at a doctors, or dentist appointment. When they got through with there appointments you would find them at the airman, NCO clubs or the Base Exchange. The next time you would see them would be Sunday afternoon wanting their papers signed saying they were there for their two days. 5 years later in the 80s I worked with different reservise units again from all over the country, and it was a different ball game. They would come in and almost take over. They were dedicated, disciplined. Airmen you were proud to serve with. Have been retired for over 23 years and am close with a lot of people still in the Air Force and they tell me they would work with any reserve unit anytime, anywhere.

Two thoughts: Once you put on the uniform and do the job, it doesn’t matter.When I was in the Coast Guard I did a brief stint at a Group Office where I stood overnight duty.  We received calls for missing boats and the like.  word was we could call on the Coast Guard Auxiliary (civilians but wear a uniform and support Coast Guard activities).  Got a call in the middle of the night about a missing boat and needed to check the local marina(s) for it.  Called the Auxiliary contact whose first reaction was “It is 2 AM!”.  Can’t recall if I mentioned they had volunteered to do this but the next thought was “OK, give me the information and I’ll go.”  Lot of respect for standing up to the commitment.

Not if you can do your job. But if you just sit around and dont help out then yes they are looked down on as worthless Meat. I was on a reserve ship at one time for 4 years Seattle Washington. We had reserves that came aboard for 2 day a month and 2 weeks every year. Some were great people some were slugs that didn't want to be there. The slugs were looked down on. RT Day Retired US Navy 72-92

In basic training and technical schools, I and most of the guys I knew envied the hell out of them. At the time, there was some sort of advertising campaign going on where the punch line was “Did you make the four-year mistake?”. When we were training with national guardsmen, we would laugh at each other for having made “the four-year mistake”.

I did not look down on reservist. I didn't think they were as well trained as the regulars. We had to practice our trade a lot more often, and for longer periods. Therefore our instruction was more varied and detailed. The reserves would do just as well if they had the same training they're Marines.

Look down on? Absolutely not. We all signed the same dotted line and raised our right hands. Do we make fun of you for being part time or a weekend warrior? Absolutely. All in good fun. Same as with other branches. Think of it as sibling rivalry. Although some guys do have malicious intent, it's rare.

I know the tags say the US Reserve, but I’m gonna butt in about the SAF. For the SAF. Active duty conscripts look forward to the day they’re in the reserves. Active duty regulars have varied opinions of the reservists. There is generally some form of respect. Reservists tend to have a lot more experience. Or at least experience in an older army. Foreign reservists, different story.

Not in general, as most Reserve members WERE ACTIVE DUTY THEMSELVES in their time, and they remain subject to call-up on little or no notice in ALL cases. National Guard they will tend to have less respect for, but that’s not as much of a factor TODAY as in the 1980s and before since many Guard units HAVE been deployed overseas into combat or at least dangerous occupation duties, and HAVE “seen the elephant”.

I shuttled between active duty, reserve duty and individual ready reserve over time. Approximately 24 months of active combat duty over 28 years. Never found there was any animosity to reservists. Look at the number that were called up for the Iraq wars. If there hadn’t been reservists, it would have been difficult to get the manpower.

I am going to answer this from the perspective of do reservists feel that active military members look down on them. I spent 3 yrs as a Canadian Reservist in the 60's. I never felt that this was the case. Perhaps this was because many of our senior non coms were men who had seen front line duty during World War II and the Korean War. I found the active service members helpful and supportive and we were keen and eager.

Since I'm now retired from 23 yrs of service in combat arms I felt free to finally answer this question…then I remembered what my grandmother beat into me about, “If you can't say anything nice…” and the period at the end of this sentence appeared . Edit… I would add that I have enormous respect for US Air Force Reserve and National Guard pilots flying A-10s, F4s and F16s from the late 70s through the 90s who saved my pickle green ass a few times.

For me, no. Imagine this. Back to back cycles. We graduated basic trainees at 11:00 a.m. then we get word that we are picking up troops the next day. That was 3 cycles back to back and we drill sergeants were tired. In come the reserve drill sergeants for 2 weeks. YES!!! I was so grateful. It was great to just be alongside th and let them handle the Red Phase. We had to guide them a bit but we let them train full throttle. Thank you reservists. Think of them as the replacements after being battle weary you are so grateful!

The Regular Forces (Canadian) certainly looked down and commented on the “weekend warriors”; until they ran short of qualified individuals (bodies). Then the Reserve person (who basically volunteered were given the same training and rifle) standing beside them in the “sun and fun places” (Kosovo; Afghanistan; Iraq; etc) had their respect.

I have often heard National Guardsmen referred to as “Weekend Warriors.” My own Guard Unit has seen more combat than a lot of regular Army units. During it’s history, it deployed to Vietnam and was in the middle of the Tet Offensive, and deployed to the Gulf in 1990, and twice more in the period from 2001–2007. My unit engaged in numerous firefights in these four deployments. I find it insulting that soldiers who have engaged in battle are disparaged by those who have not.

There's a lot of perceptions out there about active duty versus Guard/reserve. Sure, there are also stereotypes out there, but I think "hate" is also an extremely strong word too. You could also liken it to interservice rivalry between Army and Marines or Army and Air Force or even inter-branch rivalries in the active duty Army between infantry and armor for example. I think you'll find at the end of the day, the mentality is more akin to "no one picks on my brother but me.

When I was a reservist the active duty folks were openly relieved when we arrived. We were well rested, most of us had over twice the experience they did and we wanted to be there. We were the only break in work they were going to see as a unit. My hitch was Cold War era with almost no one in combat. Now the reservists go into combat in place of active duty so we reduce their number of career combat deployments.

I never did. Although we sometimes called them “"college boys” as most of them attended school. It is a great way to serve your country and leaves you the option of easily becoming an officer. It is also very flexible in that you can still preserve your desired pursuits and family obligations outside of the military. I once knew a Marine reservist that ran his mother and father’s store but still wanted to serve and have money for college. They are a big part of all branches and work to shore short falls in time of war. It it is also a good option after you have served as well. If you get out after 4 years and find yourself missing the service But still have other obligations or pursuit, you can easily go in the Reserves as long as you are not over the age limit.

I went to Bosnia as a reservist and tbh I was much more experienced than most of the young regulars. I had only been out of the regulars for a year. I think the ncos viewed me with suspicion at first but I became a member of the team very quickly.

I'm not sure of this but I have always felt insecure about this, being a reservist. I guess because the government barely recognizes you if you were. I have trouble accepting thanks for serving even though I was willing to die for my country just like any other soldier. I think I should fully recognize the effort it took and the WILLINGNESS I had when I served. That's what should count to me.

. In the US this is the standard active duty person’s reaction. Most of our services are already slack enough, that any reserve unit they will joi will be slack indeed. US reservists’ regard their civilian jobs and lives as No One, with their reserve jobs and lives as No Two. That is no doubt so in Germany and other countries too. Yet, in the US reserve life is a distant rather than a close second. Reservists spend reserve weekend mostly looking busy. It is tolerated because resrrvists want their reserve paychecks.

Some do others don't. What makes it this way though is that some of them complain about the weekend… When active duty has to endure it 24/7 pretty much. That pisses people off sometimes. I've heard it personally from lower enlisted and it drives me nuts lol. But I keep my mouth shut now lol

As a new recruit, there is a certain level of respect that is given to Anyone in the military. However, we do call US army reserve participants weekend soldiers. I guess its kind of an insult or a common saying.

I only did that when we were in the gulf war working with them. They expected 8 hour days with breaks. I worked 96 hour weeks and expected them to step to my pace, they crumbled and cried, poor babies. One guy did like it though and went active reserves and came back to our ship. Great guy.
No- What rumor or life experience led you to this belief or to ask this question?
Yes in the British Army we called them STABs Stupid Territorial Army Bastards and it bit very deep that they were being paid more than us on a lot less training and they tended to be hopeless.
Well if they do they are idiots because tomorrow their lives may depend on the reserving fighting next to them.
Navy reservists give regular USN hayfever! All those who serve are brothers and sisters for life. Remember this, "All give some, Some gave all." Many of our fallen were USNR.
no i am a 13 old mel and i wonted to be in the army but i keep having sorgryes on my back and i realy wonted to join but ther somthing difrent i can do on the base
To a point. You'll get more experience on active duty in 2 months than reservists get in a year.
